prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for 'scamming' my roomate?
 

Hey, I moved into a new apartment the 15'th december 2018 with 2 acquaintances, the apartment got 3 bedrooms, 2 of them are smaller and the bigger one is about 40% bigger than the other 2.

So before we moved in, I asked my roomates (let's call them X and Y) who was taking the big room, X says that he doesn't care, Y says that he really wants it. Now, I really wanted that room as well, so I asked "Okay, do you want to randomize(I don't know the right word) who gets it or should the highest bidder get it?(The one who offers to pay the most extra rent for it). Y says that it's not fair because he doesn't have as high of an income as I do, arguing that then I would get it and that wouldn't be fair. So I gave in and we went to [random.org](https://random.org/) and I won the roll (To clarify, the big room is now rightfully mine for the taking).

After about 3 days, Y says "I NEED the big room to fit my bed in it blablalba, what is it going to take for me to get the room instead of you?" so, once again I finally gave in and said "I really want the big room as well, but if you pay 30$ of my rent every month, you can have the room instead of me, that's what it's going to take for me to give up the big room." Y agreed.

Now fast forward to yesterday, X is really mad and he's claiming that I'm scamming him for money, he argues "It's not fair that you and me got the same m\^2 room, but you're paying 30$ less rent. He's really upset about this and he's basically saying i'm an asshole which is scamming him for money, saying that I should have taken this up with him as well.

AITA?
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking if the person who wrote the story is in the wrong. The situation involves roommates and the allocation of a bigger room. 

First, the setup: Three roommates, two smaller rooms and one bigger. Initially, they decided to roll a random number generator to determine who gets the big room. The author won. Then, after three days, the roommate Y wanted the big room and offered to pay $30 more per month. The author agreed. Now, roommate X is upset because he's paying less, which he thinks is unfair.

So, the main question is about fairness in how the room was allocated. The author argues that they followed a random method first, then made a mutual agreement with Y. X is upset that the author is paying less rent than him. But wait, the original agreement was about the big room. If all three roommates are splitting the rent equally, then the author is effectively paying less because they don't need to add the extra $30. But maybe the total rent isn't split equally? The problem isn't clear on that.

If the total rent is split equally, then the author is saving $30 by getting the bigger room, which X might see as unfair. But if the author is paying the same share as others but allowing Y to pay extra to swap rooms, then X's complaint is about why the author isn't also paying more for the big room. 

The key points are: 1) Was the room allocation fair according to the initial agreement? The author used a random method, which seems fair. Then, after the fact, Y wanted to swap and paid for it. 2) Is the payment to Y a scam? The author didn't take money from X; they let Y pay to take the room. 3) The issue is that X is now upset about the rent difference. If the rent is supposed to be split equally regardless of room size, then maybe the author should have adjusted the rent. But if the agreement was that the bigger room could be claimed through random or payment, then the author isn't in the wrong.

Also, X wasn't involved in the initial decision, so his anger might come from not being part of the process. But the original question is whether the author is wrong. The author acted in their own interest, which is understandable. The problem is whether the agreement with Y is fair and whether it's acceptable to profit from the bigger room. Since the author allowed Y to take the room in exchange for extra money, that's a reasonable arrangement. However, if the total rent isn't adjusted, then X is effectively paying more for a smaller room, which could be a point of contention. But the story doesn't specify if the rent was split equally or adjusted for room size.

In conclusion, the author isn't necessarily in the wrong because they followed the initial agreement and made a mutual arrangement with Y. X's complaint is about fairness in rent distribution, which might be a separate issue. The author isn't scamming anyone; they're entering a fair agreement with Y. So the answer should be B (No, the author is not in the wrong).
